Spartanburg One ranks 4th in the state for overall district SAT scores for the graduating class of 2020!

Nearly 41% of seniors from both Chapman and Landrum High Schools participated in the SAT examination, earning an average score of 1062. Spartanburg One seniors outperformed their counterparts in both the state (1019) and national (1030) SAT total averages. Chapman High School seniors earned a total SAT average score of 1038 and Landrum High School seniors earned a total SAT average score of 1084. Collectively, the district ranks first in overall SAT scores in Spartanburg County.

‚ÄúThese scores are representative of rigorous instruction and hard work that begins in the kindergarten classroom and extends through high school. Student success is a team effort that requires a unified focus and mission and I am so proud of the work that is being done to facilitate student achievement in Spartanburg One,‚Äù said Dr. Ron Garner, Superintendent.

To see the SAT score breakdown for school districts in the state, click here: https://ed.sc.gov/data/test-scores/national-assessments/sat/

Weather Delay | FAQ's

Will there be morning 4K classes?
- In the event of a 2-hour delay, Spartanburg One does not hold morning 4K preschool classes.

What should high school students taking classes off-campus do during a delay?
- The district will provide transportation to off-campus programs on a delayed schedule. For example, if a bus normally leaves a high school campus at 8 AM, it will leave at 10 AM during a 2-hour delay. However, if a student needs to arrive before that time, parents may take the student off-campus or the student may drive.

What time will school buildings be open on a 2-hour delay?
- All school buildings will be open to students beginning at 9 AM in the event of a 2-hour delay.

We hope this list helps answer a few of the common questions we receive during school delays!

post_text: We celebrated the 2019 Inman Mills Art Gallery winners with an unveiling ceremony prior to our May Board of Trustees meeting. A juried selection process determined the winners of the primary, elementary, middle, and high school categories. These students were recognized for their outstanding talent at our Board meeting, along with graduates of the Scholars Academy and SC Early College High School, National Merit semi-finalist, and the CHS middle school fishing team for their recent state championship! Spartanburg One is very proud of the talent and success of our students in the classroom, the arts, athletics, and in their service to our community!

The Chapman High School Band program received the 2019 SCBDA Outstanding Performance Award, the highest award given by the SCBDA, which is earned by accumulating points from the SCBDA events throughout the year. The band received:
30 points for the Superior rating at the 2A Upperstate Championships
20 points for the number of students named to Region Band (14)
30 points for the Superior rating at Concert Performance Assessment
20 points for the number of Superior ratings at Solo and Ensemble (13)
The 100 total accumulated points is a perfect score, as the band maxed-out on possible points for each category.

This is an incredible accomplishment! Way to go, band students and Mr. Horton!
